headline: Russia reportedly begins rare earth metals talks with US; Trump ‘very angry’ with Putin – as it happened | World news | The Guardian
context: Washington and Moscow have begun discussions on projects related to Russian rare earth metals, the head of Russia’s sovereign wealth fund, Kirill Dmitriev, has said.

annotations.paragraph: “Rare earth metals are an important area of cooperation and, of course, we have started discussions on various rare earth metals and projects in Russia,” he told pro-Kremlin Russian newspaper Izvestia.
annotations.reason: Provides a direct quote from Kirill Dmitriev confirming the discussions on rare earth metals.

annotations.paragraph: Dmitriev, who was part of Russia’s negotiating team at talks with US officials in Saudi Arabia in February, also said some companies have already expressed interest in the projects, without going into more detail.
annotations.reason: Adds context about Dmitriev's role and mentions interest from companies, relevant to the talks.

annotations.paragraph: Izvestia reported the cooperation may be further discussed at the next round of Russia-US talks that may take place in a couple of weeks in Saudi Arabia.
annotations.reason: Provides information on potential future discussions, relevant to the ongoing talks.

annotations.paragraph: In February, Vladimir Putin suggested that the US might be interested in exploring joint exploration for rare earth metals deposits in Russia, which has the world’s fifth-largest reserves of the metals used in lasers and military equipment.
annotations.reason: Offers context on Putin's previous suggestion and the significance of Russia's reserves.

annotations.paragraph: Donald Trump said on Thursday the US would sign a minerals and natural resources deal with Ukraine soon. Kyiv seems to have little choice but to sign a deal if it wants US military support to continue.
annotations.reason: Unrelated to the main topic of US-Russia talks on rare earth metals.

annotations.paragraph: Trump has claimed any such deal would allow the US to recoup hundreds of billions of dollars it spent on military aid to Kyiv. Ukraine wants the deal to include references to long-term US security guarantees to protect it from Russian attacks after the war is over.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the potential implications of the rare earth metals deal and its connection to US-Ukraine relations.

annotations.paragraph: But the specifics are still being negotiated and the US has so far signalled that it will not provide significant security guarantees to Ukraine as part of the agreement. You can read more about what rare earth minerals are and why Trump wants access to them in this useful explainer.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses ongoing negotiations and provides a link to further information, but the link itself is not directly relevant.

annotations.paragraph: We are now closing the Ukraine rolling coverage. Here is a summary of events:
annotations.reason: This is a transition statement and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: Washington and Moscow have reportedly begun discussions on projects related to both countries jointly exploiting Russian rare earth metals. The meeting comes after Donald Trump accused Volodymyr Zelenskyy of attempting to “renegotiate” the minerals deal with Kyiv that would give the US access to Ukraine’s rare earths.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides details on the discussions and context about Trump's accusations, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Trump said he is “pissed off” and “very angry” with Vladimir Putin over his approach to a ceasefire in Ukraine and threatened to levy tariffs on Moscow’s oil exports if the Russian president does not agree to a truce within a month.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides Trump's reaction and potential actions, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Trump signalled that he would levy a 25% or 50% tariff that would affect countries buying Russian oil in a telephone interview with NBC News early Sunday morning.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about Trump's tariff plans, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The Netherlands and Sweden both announced significant security and military aid packages to help Ukraine in its continuing efforts to fend off Russian attacks.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is not directly related to the rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Russia carried out airstrikes in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, for a second night, while Moscow accused Ukraine’s army of attacking energy sites in the Bryansk border region in a drone and artillery strike on Sunday evening.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not pertain to the rare earth metals discussions or Trump's reaction to Putin.

annotations.paragraph: Thanks for following along today. You can read all our Ukraine coverage here.
annotations.reason: This is a closing remark and does not contribute new information to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Poland and the US will sign an agreement worth nearly $2bn for the delivery of logistical support for the Patriot air defence system, Poland’s defence minister said on Monday.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the rare earth metals talks or Trump's reaction to Putin.

annotations.paragraph: “The safety of Polish skies has no price,” Wladyslaw Kosiniak-Kamysz told journalists.
annotations.reason: This quote is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks or Trump's reaction.

annotations.paragraph: The agreement with the US concerns the delivery of logistical support for the Patriot system within the armed forces and includes technical support components as well as training, Reuters reports.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Poland’s defence ministry said implementing the agreement would enable the operational readiness of Patriot launchers, which form the foundation of the Wisla programme. It aims to counter, among other things, short-range tactical ballistic missiles, including manoeuvring missiles.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Poland acquired its first two Patriot system batteries from the US in 2018 under the Wisla programme.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Galvanised by Russia’s full-scale invasion of neighbouring Ukraine, Poland has become Nato’s biggest spender in terms of the proportion of its national wealth devoted to defence. Warsaw said it will spend 4.1% of GDP on defence in 2024 with a pledge to increase this to 4.7% in 2025.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Polish prime minister Donald Tusk has recently said every adult male would receive military training and has backed Poland withdrawing from international conventions that ban the use of anti-personnel landmines and cluster munitions.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: China and India could be affected if Donald Trump introduces tariffs of 25-50% against countries buying Russian oil, analysts and officials have suggested. My colleague Dan Sabbagh reports that the US president told NBC he would impose such measures within a month “if a deal isn’t made, and if I think it was Russia’s fault”, as he vented frustration at Vladimir Putin’s delaying tactics and attempts to discredit Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on potential US tariffs related to Russian oil, which is relevant to US-Russia relations.

annotations.paragraph: Some countries, including China and India, are not participating in anti-war sanctions against Russian oil. Secondary sanctions or tariffs imposed directly on them by the US could further limit Putin’s access to oil revenue to fund the war.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the implications of US sanctions on countries buying Russian oil, relevant to the geopolitical context.

annotations.paragraph: While not joining the international sanctions against Russia, China has been wary about breaching them in case it attracts secondary penalties. Some Chinese banks, for example, have curtailed dealings with Russian companies for fear of being barred from the international banking system.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on China's cautious stance regarding sanctions, relevant to the broader geopolitical situation.

annotations.paragraph: Volodymyr Zelenskyy has marked the third anniversary of the Ukrainian army retaking Bucha, which was seized by Russia soon after Vladimir Putin ordered a full-scale invasion of Ukraine on 24 February 2022.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of US-Russia talks on rare earth metals.

annotations.paragraph: Ukrainian forces took back control of the small towns of Bucha and Irpin to the northwest of Kyiv in late March in 2022 as Russian soldiers quickly abandoned their attempt to seize the capital Kyiv.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of US-Russia talks on rare earth metals.

annotations.paragraph: As Russian troops withdrew from Bucha, the scale of the destruction and horror there became clear.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the situation in Bucha, which is not directly related to the rare earth metals talks.

annotations.paragraph: Witnesses of alleged atrocities in Bucha told the Guardian that Russian soldiers had fired on men fleeing the town, and had killed civilians at will.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details events in Bucha, unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks.

annotations.paragraph: Kyiv says more than 1,400 people were killed in Bucha during the occupation including 37 children, more than 175 people were found in mass graves and torture chambers, and at least 9,000 Russian war crimes have been identified.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides statistics on the Bucha situation, not relevant to the rare earth metals discussions.

annotations.paragraph: Moscow denies accusations of executions, rapes and torture by its occupying troops who left bodies in the streets when they fled.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Moscow's denial of war crimes, which is not pertinent to the rare earth metals talks.

annotations.paragraph: Paying tribute to Ukrainians who have been killed in the war and expressing gratitude to Ukrainian soldiers still fighting to defend their country, Zelenskyy wrote in a post on X on Monday:

annotations.paragraph: And the world saw what the Russian occupation truly is: people killed in the streets, people tortured, graves in the yards of ordinary houses.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of rare earth metals talks between Russia and the US.

annotations.paragraph: Since then, no one in the world can say they do not know what Ukraine is defending.

annotations.paragraph: In an earlier post, we reported that Sweden announced a fresh military aid package to Kyiv worth about 16 billion kronor ($1.5bn; £1.2bn).

annotations.paragraph: Now, Dutch defence minister Ruben Brekelmans and defence secretary Gijs Tuinman have announced the Netherlands will allocate €2bn ($2.2bn; £1.7bn) to support Kyiv this year.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of Russia-US talks on rare earth metals.

annotations.paragraph: The security assistance will include support for Ukraine’s Drone Line project, a military initiative that will broaden the use of drones within elite units of the ground forces and the state border guard service.

annotations.paragraph: Unveiling details of the project in a Facebook post last month, Ukrainian defence minister Rustem Umerov wrote:

annotations.paragraph: We are launching a revolutionary project that will radically strengthen our brigades and scale the experience of effectively destroying the enemy - the Drone Line.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of Russia-US talks on rare earth metals.

annotations.paragraph: This is a new standard of warfare, where unmanned systems are becoming a key element of combat operations, helping our defenders perform the most difficult tasks.

annotations.paragraph: The Netherlands has been a staunch ally to Ukraine since Russia’s full-scale invasion three years ago, reportedly providing Kyiv with about €7.33bn ($7.87bn) in support to date.

annotations.paragraph: In a video posted to X ahead of the Madrid meeting, Kaja Kallas said today marks three weeks since Ukraine agreed to a ceasefire but “Russia is playing games and not really wanting peace”.

annotations.paragraph: The Madrid meeting will also discuss European defence more generally as, she said, “all kinds of threats are coming our way”.

annotations.paragraph: Europe’s top diplomat, Kaja Kallas, has urged Russia to show goodwill and agree on a ceasefire in Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: On Monday, the EU’s high representative for foreign affair said “giving back Ukrainian children that have been deported to Russia” and “releasing prisoners of war” were examples of gestures Russia could make to show goodwill.

annotations.paragraph: Speaking before a meeting of European foreign ministers in Madrid to discuss the war in Ukraine, she also called on the US to apply pressure on the Kremlin to put an end to the three-year-old conflict.

annotations.paragraph: Meanwhile, the French foreign minister, Jean-Noel Barrot, said Russia owed a clear response to the US on whether it wants to go on a peace path at all amid Donald Trump’s comments that he was “very angry” with Russia’s Vladimir Putin.

annotations.paragraph: Speaking in the northwestern Russian city of Murmansk on Friday, Putin had suggested the establishment of an interim government in Ukraine under UN supervision, which would be in place “in order to hold a democratic election (in Ukraine), in order to bring in a competent government trusted by people”.

annotations.paragraph: By “competent government” he means one not led by Volodymyr Zelenskyy, the current Ukrainian president. Ukrainian law does not allow elections under martial law, which was declared when Russia launched its full-scale invasion in February 2022.

annotations.paragraph: Welcome back to our live coverage of Russia’s war on Ukraine. We are leading today’s blog with Donald Trump saying he was “very angry” and “pissed off” over Vladimir Putin’s approach to a ceasefire in Ukraine, in comments that mark a huge shift in tone in the way the US president usually speaks about the Russian leader.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces Trump's reaction to Putin's actions, which is central to the article's headline.

annotations.paragraph: Trump also took aim at the Russian president’s criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s credibility, despite the US President having previously called his Ukrainian counterpart a “dictator”.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights Trump's criticism of Putin, which is relevant to the article's focus on US-Russia relations.

annotations.paragraph: Putin recently said that Zelenskyy – who was democratically elected in 2019 – lacks the legitimacy to sign a peace deal and suggested that Ukraine needed external governance.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Putin's view of Zelenskyy, relevant to the geopolitical narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Trump, who is eager for Kyiv and Moscow to swiftly agree to a broad ceasefire deal, indicated he would levy a 25% or 50% tariff that would affect countries buying Russian oil in a telephone interview with NBC News.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about Trump's potential economic actions against Russia, which is related to the broader geopolitical context.

annotations.paragraph: “If Russia and I are unable to make a deal on stopping the bloodshed in Ukraine, and if I think it was Russia’s fault, which it might not be, but if I think it was Russia’s fault, I am going to put secondary tariffs on oil, on all oil coming out of Russia,” Trump said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct quote from Trump about potential tariffs, adding relevant context to the geopolitical situation.

annotations.paragraph: “That would be that if you buy oil from Russia, you can’t do business in the United States. There will be a 25% tariff on all … on all oil, a 25 to 50-point tariff on all oil.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the potential tariffs, contributing to the understanding of the economic implications.

annotations.paragraph: Trump continued: “I was very angry, pissed off” when Putin “started getting into Zelenskyy’s credibility, because that’s not going in the right location, you understand?”
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into Trump's personal reaction to Putin's actions, which is relevant to the diplomatic tensions discussed.

annotations.paragraph: He said “new leadership means you’re not gonna have a deal for a long time, right” and that he wanted to exert pressure on the Kremlin, which has only agreed to limited maritime and energy ceasefires so far.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant commentary on the challenges of reaching a deal with Russia, adding to the narrative of diplomatic efforts.

annotations.paragraph: Seemingly responding to Trump’s comments, Zelenskyy said in his Sunday night address that Putin “does not care about diplomacy”, adding that attacks have continued to attack his country despite ceasefire proposals (being suggested by Washington over recent weeks).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the geopolitical tensions involving Russia, Ukraine, and the US, which is relevant to the broader narrative of US-Russia relations.

annotations.paragraph: “For several weeks now, there has been a US proposal for an unconditional ceasefire. And almost every day, in response to this proposal, there are Russian drones, bombs, artillery shelling and ballistic strikes,” the Ukrainian president said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific details about the ongoing conflict and US diplomatic efforts, which are relevant to the article's focus on US-Russia relations.

annotations.paragraph: “Russia deserves increased pressure - all the tough measures that can break its capacity to wage war and sustain the system that wants nothing but war,” Zelensky added.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides Zelensky's perspective on the conflict and calls for action, which is relevant to the geopolitical context of the article.

annotations.paragraph: In some other developments:
annotations.reason: This paragraph serves as a transition and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph:
Donald Trump said Volodymyr Zelenskyy wants to back out of a critical minerals deal, which would grant the US access to Ukraine’s rare mineral reserves.
   “He’s trying to back out of the rare earth deal and if he does that he’s got some problems, big, big problems,” Trump told reporters yesterday. 
   “He wants to be a member of Nato, but he’s never going to be a member of Nato. He understands that.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly relates to the rare earth metals talks and provides Trump's perspective, which is central to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: Russia bombed the city of Kharkiv in north-eastern Ukraine for the second night in a row, injuring two people, sparking fires and damaging a kindergarten and private houses, Ukrainian officials said early on Monday. The attacks lasted most of the night, said Kharkiv’s mayor, Ihor Terekhov. Zelenskyy on Sunday said Moscow had fired more than 1,000 drones in the past week and called for a response from the US and other allies.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the rare earth metals talks and focuses on military actions in Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Russia’s defence ministry claimed on Sunday that its forces had gained control over Zaporizhzhia settlement in Ukraine’s Donetsk region. The village is unrelated to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, which is in another region. The Russian claim was reported by Reuters, which said it was not able to verify it. The village is 7km from the border of Ukraine’s central Dnipropetrovsk region. The Donetsk region borders Dnipropetrovsk to the east.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the rare earth metals talks and focuses on military claims in Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: The Ukrainian air force said Russia launched 131 drones and two ballistic missiles during overnight attacks, 57 of which were shot down and another 45 drones did not reach their targets, likely due to electronic countermeasures. The military did not specify what happened to the remaining 29 drones.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the rare earth metals talks and focuses on military actions in Ukraine.

annotations.paragraph: Russia’s air defence units intercepted and destroyed 66 Ukrainian drones overnight, the Russian defence ministry said this morning. 41 of the drones were destroyed over the border Bryansk region, 24 over the Kaluga region and one over the Kursk region. There were no immediate reports of any casualties.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the rare earth metals talks and focuses on military actions in Ukraine.
